segments.text: Well, can I still ask you about, um...
The Connecticut... Well, can you tell me about...
So, that's about... You just wrote articles when you're underneath?
Yeah, what about the Connecticut conference?
And, well, what kind of effect did that have?
It seems like it would have been very difficult for you to get around.
So when the climate had changed, that's when you decided to come out, right?
You felt as though it was safer?
OK. What reasons did you have for coming out at the time you did?
Oh, well, the first seven had come out having done their time.
Would you mind being a little more specific on how the climate had changed?
So did you think you'd have a better chance at a trial, perhaps?
Did you think you might have a better chance in the trial since...
I'm sorry, when you came out, after coming out, that perhaps they'd...
Perhaps they'd... We already were sentenced.
Okay, well... You mean... That you could have appealed it?
Because it was not before a trial, before a trial.
Well, what did you write in your book, The Enemy Forgotten?
You wrote that while you were underground?
I took a letter to the press.
They told me that I would appear fully square.
that the American people, by being misled to see the enemy abroad, the Soviet Union was forgetting the real enemy.
And of course, the captors, the tremendous captains across those who ruled the country, had the enemy historically, a whole history of America
Well, I'd like to talk about Hoover for a minute, his counterintelligence programs, his counterintelligence programs that he explicitly gave admission to forgery by typewriter.
And you think it's possibly Aldrich Hiss' The Pumpkin Case, the letters they found?
Well, I myself have believed the evidence.
The first time there's any public evidence is when I have my book from the documents of the FBI itself.
and that they could forge typewriters, principle typewriters, in a much longer period of time.
And then in this instance, they preferred the use of firemen, the first of the name was Fortree and Hadley.
And that was the first evidence that had ever been made public that the FBI did know how to forge typewriters.
that that was in charge of his case.
Now, in history, there was a court in Antwerp that said, I have been framed by typewriters.
Because they claimed that certain documents were written on this typewriter.
Do you know other people that had that done, too, besides William Albertson that you cite in the book?
Well, William Albertson was an ex-skeleton in the party.
Aren't a lot of the pages that you have, of the 20,000 or so pages, blackened?
The only things I could get were black pages, not a single word.
And I had made trips abroad.
I know they'd go through a lot and all that, but not a word.
And they only gave... And when the FBI, the pages you have from the FBI are only of your exploits, correct?
It doesn't deal with the others who were on the ground.
So have the others gotten theirs, or have they?
No, I think I'm the only one.
I want to thank the young lawyers.
Well, can I ask you about Leavenworth?
You seem, from your book, it's as though you were treated worse than some criminals because you were a communist.
I think it was part of the climate.
Somebody, some man in prison said,
come right to his congressman and say, well, look, how is this commie getting along so well?
Why do you think he has a hefty job in prison and so forth?
And that this would create a furor which would affect his leadership.
The furor was better than the soft-eye communism.
And so they decided to be out there.
They were not knowing the other soft-eye communism.
They were going to be hired on the top of this.
And that's what they're trying to do.
So they're just protecting the wardens, and we're just trying to protect themselves, then?
Yes, at one point, there was a word coming in that they had been cited by one of the judges.
And even your relationship with your lawyer was, your supposedly confidential was not, was invaded, right?
My lawyer would come twice a year down there to discuss with me, possibly.
Well, was John Winston, he was in... Henry Winston.
He was in dire need of medical care.
He had a brain tumor, correct?
Well, why do you think they... Why do you think they were so negligent?
Or do you think it was to appear not soft on communism?
Or it could have happened to... Do you think it was because it was Henry Winston?
Or could it have happened to any prisoner?
I would say it could have happened to others as well.
Although one would have to be in the mind of putting a position or examining whether he was right or he was wrong.
It's going to have to happen.
It's going to have to happen.
It's going to have to happen.
It's going to have to happen.
It's going to have to happen.
Now, of course, I had a big, you know, level of country where the carpenter shop, I had actually, and I did my kneecap.
And there I had a doctor and a patella kneecaps put together and sutured together.
And I had a Dr. Hyde.
Well, getting back to your confidential conversations with Mr. App, you said something about that there were, that they created, they fabricated conversations they assumed you had made?
In one case, they had John App, according to the document, telling me about...
I'd say that the party organizations come to town and get at this point exactly where it is, and the mentioning names of people who were involved, who were doing vocates, and so on.
I never knew the people that were mentioned there, and I never knew anything about the communist organization in that particular town.

I believe part of that is that we think back of the whole system of the FBI, including their organization, that Greta was listening in on this, learning the fabric of the stories in order to make it clear that he was really out of his job and that something sinister was really happening.
And also, I don't exclude the fact
Possibly they were trying to get some, create some artificial and to ditch on that in case they wanted to .
And Mr. Winston, it took until 61 under an order of clemency
from JFK for him to be released?
Which they tried to prevent you from working in to begin.
So you were in contact with Gus for a while, Gus Hall, in Leavenworth?
When I came to Leavenworth as well, and a little bit, as I said, he was picked up three months after.
And he still had about a year to go.
So were you allowed to collaborate on papers or?
We were ordered very strictly that I could write nothing.
So did you talk about the party?
We talked about what we could gather.
And also, when you were leaving the prison, when you were getting out, the FBI wanted to avoid publicity about that, so they shipped you in secret to New York
Well, what happened there was when Kess Hall was released, he was released directly.
Well, what have you been doing since then?
Can you hold on one minute?
I'm going to change the tape again.
Just give me a couple more minutes, I promise you.
